quiz.title: Introduction to React Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.
If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text: Which of the following describe React as a library? Select all that apply.

answers.comments: Correct! React helps us write declarative code, which makes our code easier to understand. Declarative code:  Describes what a program should accomplish (or what the end result should be) Leaves the determination of how to get to the end result up to the program
answers.comments_html:
Correct!

React helps us write declarative code, which makes our code easier to understand. Declarative code:

  • Describes what a program should accomplish (or what the end result should be)
  • Leaves the determination of how to get to the end result up to the program

answers.comments: Yes! React encourages us to structure our applications as "components": the building blocks of our web page that handle their own data and UI logic, that can be "composed" together with other components to put together a complete app.
answers.comments_html:
Yes!

React encourages us to structure our applications as "components": the building blocks of our web page that handle their own data and UI logic, that can be "composed" together with other components to put together a complete app.

answers.comments: Nice One! One great thing about React is that it works in a few different environments. Once you learn the key concepts of working with React to create client-side web applications, you can also more easily learn React Native and write native mobile apps using React, or use tools like Next.js and Gatsby to write server-rendered React.
answers.comments_html: Nice One! One great thing about React is that it works in a few different environments. Once you learn the key concepts of working with React to create client-side web applications, you can also more easily learn React Native and write native mobile apps using React, or use tools like Next.js and Gatsby to write server-rendered React.

answers.comments: While you can implement a MVVM architectural pattern in your React program, it isn't inherently a MVVM framework.
answers.comments_html:
While you can implement a MVVM architectural pattern in your React program, it
isn't inherently a MVVM framework.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Of the code examples below, which uses declarative syntax?

answers.text: const header = h1 className="main"Hello from React!/h1; ReactDOM.render(header, document.querySelector("#container"));
answers.html:
const header = <h1 className="main">Hello from React!</h1>;

ReactDOM.render(header, document.querySelector("#container"));
answers.comments: Correct! With declarative syntax, we are able to leave the determination of how to get to the end result up to the program! Therefore, we don't need to lay out every step that needs to happen, like we do with imperative syntax.
answers.comments_html:
Correct!

With declarative syntax, we are able to leave the determination of how to get to the end result up to the program! Therefore, we don't need to lay out every step that needs to happen, like we do with imperative syntax.

answers.text: const header = document.createElement("h1"); header.textContent = "Hi!"; header.className = "main"; const container = document.querySelector("#container"); container.append(header);
answers.html:
const header = document.createElement("h1");
header.textContent = "Hi!";
header.className = "main";
const container = document.querySelector("#container");
container.append(header);
answers.comments: This code is more imperative than declarative, since we need to specify each step of the DOM creation process in our code. With declarative syntax, we are able to leave the determination of how to get to the end result up to the program. Therefore, we don't need to lay out every step that needs to happen, like we do with imperative syntax.
answers.comments_html: This code is more imperative than declarative, since we need to specify each step of the DOM creation process in our code. With declarative syntax, we are able to leave the determination of how to get to the end result up to the program. Therefore, we don't need to lay out every step that needs to happen, like we do with imperative syntax.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Match the term with the correct description.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

answers.right:
Describes what the end result should be, not the specific actions or steps to
get to that result.

Explicitly describes the specific actions or steps for getting to the end
result.

matches.text:
Describes what the end result should be, not the specific actions or steps to
get to that result.

Explicitly describes the specific actions or steps for getting to the end
result.

questions.question_text: Which of the following commands will download all the packages listed in a package.json file?

answers.html: $ npm install
answers.comments: Correct! We run npm install to download all the packages listed in the package.json file, and track which versions were installed.
answers.comments_html: Correct! We run npm install to download all the packages listed in the package.json file, and track which versions were installed.

answers.html: $ npm init
answers.comments: npm init creates a new package.json file, which helps set up a dependencies for a new project.
answers.comments_html: npm init creates a new package.json file, which helps set up a dependencies for a new project.

answers.html: $ npm start
answers.comments: Typically, npm start is a command for running your application, like starting the dev server for a React application.
answers.comments_html: Typically, npm start is a command for running your application, like starting the dev server for a React application.

answers.html: $ npm run
answers.comments: The npm run command lets you run custom scripts defined in your package.json file.
answers.comments_html: The npm run command lets you run custom scripts defined in your package.json file.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

___ is a package manager for JavaScript that works with your JavaScript
project directories via the command line, allowing you to install packages of
preexisting code.

questions.question_text: Why is React useful for developers? Select all that apply.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:What is React?React Dev ToolsReact NativeNext.jsGatsby
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • What is React?
  • React Dev Tools
  • React Native
  • Next.js
  • Gatsby

answers.text: React allows us to create reusable UI components.
answers.comments: Correct! React encourages us to structure our applications as "components": the building blocks of our web page that handle their own data and UI logic, that can be "composed" together with other components to put together a complete app.
answers.comments_html:
Correct!

React encourages us to structure our applications as "components": the building blocks of our web page that handle their own data and UI logic, that can be "composed" together with other components to put together a complete app.

answers.text: React allows us to create applications that can change data, without reloading the page.
answers.html:
React allows us to create applications that can change data, without reloading
the page.
answers.comments: Nailed it! By using state, we are able to change data in our applications without reloading the page!
answers.comments_html:
Nailed it!

By using state, we are able to change data in our applications without reloading the page!

answers.text: React has a great set of developer tools that make it easier to view our components in the browser and debug what's happening under the hood.
answers.html:
React has a great set of developer tools that make it easier to view our
components in the browser and debug what's happening under the hood.
answers.comments: 100%! Check out the React Dev Tools so you can start debugging like a React pro!
answers.comments_html:
100%!

Check out the React Dev Tools so you can start debugging like a React pro!

answers.text: It works in many different environments allowing developers to build not only web applications, but mobile applications and server-rendered React.
answers.html:
It works in many different environments allowing developers to build not only
web applications, but mobile applications and server-rendered React.
answers.comments: Nice One! One great thing about React is that it works in a few different environments. Once you learn the key concepts of working with React to create client-side web applications, you can also more easily learn React Native and write native mobile apps using React, or use tools like Next.js and Gatsby to write server-rendered React.
answers.comments_html:
Nice One!

One great thing about React is that it works in a few different environments. Once you learn the key concepts of working with React to create client-side web applications, you can also more easily learn React Native and write native mobile apps using React, or use tools like Next.js and Gatsby to write server-rendered React.
